lat: Et ego et tū manūs sustulimus.
eng: Both you and I raised our hands.

lat: Et tū et frāter meus manūs sustulistis.
eng: Both you and my brother lifted up your hands.

lat: Et tū ades et frāter tuus.
eng: Both you and your brother are here.

lat: Appius et soror eius et frāter meus manūs sustulērunt.
eng: Appius and his sister and my brother lifted up their hands.

lat: Nunc mihi nihil librī, nihil litterae, nihil doctrīna prōdest.
eng: Now neither do books avail me, nor letters, nor does learning.

lat: Neque tū adfuistī neque frāter tuus.
eng: Neither you nor your brother was present.
It is the wish of the Roman people.
The army started from the camp.
The senate decreed.
A large proportion of the men fled.

lat: Cōnstat Rōmam nōn sine labōre conditam esse.
eng: It is agreed that Rome was not built without toil.

He said that the enemy was near.
He answered that he would go.
I perceive that your brother is a brave man.
I see that the fact is so.

lat: He says that he is not ready.
eng: Sē parātum esse negat.

lat: He said he would never do this.
eng: Sē hoc umquam esse factūrum negāvit.

lat: He says he has done nothing.
eng: Negat sē quidquam fēcisse.

He says that he is in Asia.
He said that he was in Asia.
He says he was (or has been) in Asia.

lat: Spērat plērumque adulēscēns diū sē vīctūrum esse.
eng: A young man generally hopes to live a long time.

lat: Hoc sē factūrum esse minātus est.
eng: He threatened to do this.

lat: Spērāvit fore ut id sibi contingeret.
eng: He hoped that this would fall to his lot.
I hope that Carthage will be annihilated.

lat: Cōnstituit Caesar ut Antōnius cōnsul fieret.
eng: Caesar determined that Antony should be made consul.
Caesar determined that Antony should be made consul.

It seemed good to me (I resolved) to do this.

lat: Et pater mihi et māter mortuī sunt.
eng: Both my father and mother are dead.

lat: Et ego et soror mea ad praetōrem vocātī erāmus.
eng: Both my sister and I had been summoned to the praetor.

lat: Fidēs tua et pietās laudandae sunt.
eng: Your good faith and dutifulness are to be praised.

lat: Glōria, dīvitiae, honōrēs incerta ac cadūca sunt.
eng: Glory, riches, and distinctions are uncertain and perishable things.
Good faith and a sense of duty are to be praised.

lat: Spernendae igitur sunt dīvitiae et honōrēs.
eng: Riches then, and distinctions, are to be despised.

lat: Mihi prīncipātus atque imperium dēlātum est.
eng: The sovereignty and chief power were offered to me.

The good and wise men are being banished.

He is friendly to Cicero.

lat: Multa fuēre eius et praeclāra facta.
eng: Many and distinguished were his deeds.

lat: Multa ab eō praeclārē facta sunt.

lat: Ubi est puer cui librum dedistī?
eng: Where is the boy to whom you gave the book?
I, who did the deed, am here.

lat: Pater eius et māter quī aderant.
eng: His father and mother who were present.

lat: Dīvitiae et honōrēs quae cadūca sunt.
eng: Riches and distinctions, which are perishable.

lat: Tīmoleōn, id quod difficilius putātur, sapientius tulit secundam quam adversam fortūnam.
eng: Timoleon, though this  is thought the more difficult task, bore prosperity more wisely than adversity.

lat: Multae cīvitātēs ā Cyrō dēfēcērunt, quae rēs multōrum bellōrum causa fuit.
eng: Many states revolted from Cyrus; and this was the cause of many wars.

lat: Ille, id quod audiistī, Rōmae mortem obiit.
eng: He, as you have heard, died at Rome.
This is the man I saw.
He found the books he wanted.

lat: Volscī cīvitātem, quam habēbant optimam, perdidērunt.
eng: The Volsci lost the best city they had.

lat: Equitēs, quōs paucōs sēcum habuit, dīmīsit.
eng: He sent away the few mounted men whom he had with him.

lat: Quā erat animī benignitāte, omnibus veniam dedit.
eng: Such was his kindliness, he pardoned all.
I am the man I always was.
Those who saw this wept.

I hate one who (or a man who) does this.

lat: Quī tum tē dēfendit, is hodiē accūsat.
eng: The very man who then defended you is today accusing you.

My conqueror.
The truth.

lat: Ait sē mulierem aspicere quae piscēs vēndat.
eng: He says that he sees a woman who is selling fish.

lat: Ad rēgem vēnī, quem cum vīdissem...
eng: I came to the king, and when I had seen him...

lat: Dīxit prōditōrem esse eum ... quem brevī peritūrum esse.
eng: He said that he was a traitor ... and that he would soon perish.

lat: Nēmō est quīn tē dēmentem putet.
eng: There is no one but thinks you mad (=the whole world thinks, etc.)
There was no one whom I did not see.
He was the first who did this.
It is the farmer whom the lawyer praises.
Thebes, which is the capital of Boeotia.
That is true piety.
He is such as (of the same character as) he has ever been.
I have as much pleasure as you.

lat: Tot erant mīlitēs quot maris flūctūs.
eng: The soldiers were as many as the waves of the sea.
He is the same as he has always been.

lat: Rēs perācta est eōdem modō quō anteā.
eng: The thing has been done in the same manner as before.

lat: Quot adstābant hominēs, tot erant sententiae.
eng: There were as many opinions as there were men standing by.

lat: Quālis fuit domina, tālem ancillam inveniēs.
eng: You will find the maid of the same character as her mistress was.
I hate such men as these.
This great number of men.
So good a man as this.

lat: Ubi tū es, ibi est frāter tuus.
eng: Your brother is in the same place as you.

lat: Quālis fuerit frāter tuus, tālem tē esse dīcunt.
eng: They say that you are of the same character as your brother was.
Sitting delights me.
Doing nothing is a pleasure to me.
Lying is disgraceful.
Man, to whom living is thinking.

lat: Errāre, nescīre, et malum et turpe dūcimus.
eng: To err, to be ignorant, we deem both unfortunate and disgraceful.

lat: Laudārī, quod plērīsque grātissimum est, mihi molestissimum est.
eng: To be praised, which is very pleasant to most men, is to me most disagreeable.
Good ploughing is good farming.

lat: Haec perpetī et patriā carēre, miserrimum est.
eng: To endure these things and to be deprived of one’s country, is most wretched.
The doing (the having done, the being about to do) this.

lat: Tē hoc dīcere mihi est grātissimum.
eng: Your saying this is most welcome to me.

lat: Multī aliōs laudant, ut ab illīs laudentur.
eng: Many men praise others, that they may be praised by them.

lat: Multī aliōs laudābant, ut ab illīs laudārentur.
eng: Many men were praising others, in order to be praised by them.

lat: Gallīnae avēsque reliquae pennīs fovent pullōs, nē frīgore laedantur.
eng: Hens and other birds cherish their young with their feathers, that they may not be hurt by the cold.

lat: Gallīnae avēsque reliquae pennīs fovēbant pullōs, nē frīgore laederentur.
eng: Hens and other birds were cherishing their young with their feathers, that they might not be hurt by the cold.

lat: Medicō puto aliquid dandum esse, quō sit studiōsior.
eng: I think that something should be given to the physician, that he may be the more attentive.

lat: Hoc fēcī nē tibi displicērem nēve amīcīs tuīs nocērem.
eng: I did this to avoid displeasing you, or injuring your friends.

lat: Haec scrībō (scrīpsī, scrībam, scrīpserō) ut bonō sīs animō.
eng: I write (have written, shall write, shall have written) this, in order that you may be in good spirits.

lat: Haec scrībēbam (scrīpsī, scrīpseram) ut bonō essēs animō.
eng: I was writing (wrote, had written) this, in order that you might be in good spirits.

lat: Dīcō eum vēnisse ut pācem peteret.
eng: I say he came to seek peace.
